newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Brent crude plays catch-up to NYMEX gains.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Brent crude plays catch-up to NYMEX gains.

text.p: Brent crude futures rose in thin Thursday trade catching-up with gains in NYMEX crude and heating oil chalked up on the eve of New Year, dealers said.
Sentiment remained bullish on arctic-like weather in Europe and possibly higher prices ahead due to tight inventories.
February Brent on SIMEX traded up to a high of $24.25 per barrel, up 44 cents from its previous close.

"These are just adjustments to where WTI and heating oil went on Tuesday. The arbitrage had widened more than $2.00," a commission house broker said, noting NYMEX February crude oil had risen 55 cents on Tuesday to $25.92 per barrel.
IPE's February Brent ended its Tuesday session at $23.81 per barrel, but was expected to open shortly at markedly higher levels aided by prolonged freezing weather in Europe.
But dealers said that while weather remained the driving force of the markets near term, volume was still thin.
"(SIMEX) Brent is valued around $24.20. There is no real market to justify anything higher before London comes in," another dealer said.
IPE's gas oil futures were expected to resume trading today at up to $3-4 a tonne higher. Cold weather and historically low stocks were seen keeping the firm trend intact.
